awd_titl_txt: A Spatiotemporal Investigation of Heat Wave Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will analyze changes in the spatial and temporal patterns of heat waves and explore relationships between their size and physical variables, such as soil moisture and land cover, with the goal of developing predictive models of heat wave occurrence.  Extreme heat is the most common weather-related cause of death. A better understanding of heat wave size, intensity and drivers of these characteristics will enhance public safety by identifying where and under what conditions heat waves are likely to be larger and/or more intense, so that public health interventions such as warnings, education, and staging of cooling/hydration stations, etc. can be planned. Novel integration of methods from climatology and landscape ecology will allow for development of a spatial database of heat waves that can be used to answer questions, such as how climate and land-surface change impacts heat wave size and intensity. Broader impacts of the project include implications for public health, urban planning, and disaster management and preparedness as well as land management and policy. Through workshops with heat-health stakeholders the project will promote dissemination of results and their translation into recommendations for public health and emergency management. The project has education and outreach activities designed to promote the inclusion of underrepresented groups and foster increased minority participation in geography and related STEM fields.

This project will address the critical need to improve the spatial and temporal modeling of heat waves. Spatial analysis techniques from the fields of geography, landscape ecology, and climatology will be combined to examine the spatiotemporal evolution of heat waves. Heat waves will be tracked daily using a novel combination of simple geometric concepts, formalized as shape metrics, and a clustering algorithm. Regions within heat waves where conditions are expected to pose a significant risk to human and environmental health will be a key focus. Using statistical models and the concept of critical climate periods these regions will be linked to geophysical variables including atmospheric and land surface variables that influence surface air temperature and humidity. The two main research questions are: (1) what changes can be observed in spatiotemporal characteristics of heat waves, such as size and shape? and (2) what are the relationships among statistical characteristics of heat waves (frequency, magnitude, duration), spatial characteristics of heat waves (size, shape, connectivity), and geophysical variables?  The overarching goal of the project is to develop models to predict these heat wave characteristics. This research project will focus on heat waves in the continental United States, with implications for managing heat wave impacts globally.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project analyzed changes in the spatial and temporal patterns of heat waves and explored relationships between such extreme event characteristics (e.g. size, duration, shape, magnitude)  and physical variables, such as soil moisture and land cover, with the goal of developing predictive models of heat wave impacts.  There are broad impacts as extreme heat is the most common weather-related cause of death, affecting not just vulnerable populations. A better understanding of heat wave size, intensity and drivers of these characteristics will enhance public safety by identifying where and under what conditions heat waves are likely to be larger and/or more intense, so that public health interventions such as warnings/education and staging of cooling/hydration stations can be planned for. This project addressed the critical need to improve the spatiotemporal modeling of heat waves. Spatial analysis techniques from the fields of geography, landscape ecology, remote sensing, and climatology were combined to examine the spatiotemporal evolution of heat waves across the U.S.. Through this project new ways to define heat wave durations and extents were derived, and a new spatial metric was developed that combines heat wave frequency, magnitude, duration, and areal extent to give a more holistic characterization of these events than was previously possible.  Overall, results show a considerable increase in the heat wave burden across the U.S. during the last four decades, and the pattern is not only isolated to a single region. A heat wave persistence metric was also developed to define regions across the U.S. with consistent heat wave exposure and impact. With such a metric we can link patterns of human and environmental health and other longer term impacts with persistent extreme heat that was not possible to explore previously. Large variability in heat wave exposure and impacts has been discovered by this work and this informs public health and emergency management to pinpoint susceptibility to heat and allow for improved planning and decision making.

The intellectual merit of the project lies in its novel integration of methods across multiple disciplines in order to examine spatial patterns of heat waves in ways that have not previously been possible due to big data and methodological constraints.  For example, from this project, an application of these new methods allows for development of a spatial database of heat waves that can be used to answer questions, such as how climate and land-surface change impacts heat wave size and intensity. This dataset and the newly developed Heat Severity and Coverage Index (HSCI) served as the crucial backbone of the project and represents an extreme improvement of previous spatial datasets on heat wave severity and duration (See publications for more information, Keelings et al. 2020 and Keellings et al. 2018; Wanyama et al. 2023). Additionally, due to the interdisciplinary nature of this project our newly developed spatial metric, called the Combined Heat wave Characteristic Index (CHCI), allows one to understand cumulative local scale impacts of extreme heat. This index differs from other published indices related to heat waves in that the index includes an additional output that helps to understand and to interpret what specific heat wave characteristics are driving such local scale trends.

Broader impacts of the project also include implications for public health, urban planning, and disaster management/preparedness as well as land management and policy. Through workshops with heat-health stakeholders the project promoted dissemination of results and their translation into recommendations for public health/emergency management preparedness. From such workshops research was developed on heat wave definition cohesion, as there is no standard definition for emergency managers and meteorologists to use. Without a standard heat wave definition, and an understanding of the characteristics behind such a definition, it can be expected that different policies, management practices, and funding allocations are occurring across the county in response to extreme heat. The findings of the research effort have been published in several academic papers that can inform readers. The project had numerous education and outreach activities that promoted the inclusion of underrepresented groups and fostered increased minority participation in the physical sciences including workshops, panels, teaching modules, and student engagement events. The project has thus far resulted in no less than six published academic papers led or co-authored by students involved in the project and four more are currently under review. This project also gave advanced training in geospatial analysis to numerous students who earned undergraduate and graduate degrees as a result of work undertaken on the project. It is also worthy to note that the project has increased the number of women and minorities pursuing advanced degrees in geography and the spatial sciences.
